00043 std::string Err::m_errorPrefix="FATAL ERROR:";
00044 
00045 void Err::setErrorPrefix(const std::string& prefix) {
00046   m_errorPrefix=prefix;
00047 }

00049   /** 
00050    * @brief This function gets around the problem of static variable
00051    * initialization as local static variables work more consistently.
00052    * @return Param - Our static parameters for this class.
00053    */
00054   Err::Param &Err::getParam() {
00055     static Param m_Param;
00056     return m_Param;
00057   }
00058 
00059   void Err::errAbort(const std::string &msg) {
00060     errAbort(msg,m_errorPrefix);
00061   }
00062 
00063   /** 
00064    * Print the message supplied and abort program.
00065    * @param msg - Message for user about what went wrong.
00066    * @param prefix - Prefix to add to the error message.
00067    */
00068   void Err::errAbort(const std::string& msg,const std::string& prefix){ // throw (Except) {
00069     unsigned int size = getParam().m_ErrHandlers.size();
00070     if(size <= 0) {
00071       cout << "Can't have no error handlers." << endl;
00072     }
00073     std::string errMsg = prefix + msg;;
00074     // GUI's do not like the newline
00075     if(getParam().m_NewLineOnError) {
00076         errMsg = "\n" + errMsg;
00077     }
00078     getParam().m_ErrHandlers[size - 1]->handleError(errMsg);
00079   }
00080 
00081   /** 
00082    * Add a new handler for errors.
00083    * @param handler - Pointer to handler to call when things go wrong.
00084    */
00085   void Err::pushHandler(ErrHandler *handler) {
00086     getParam().m_ErrHandlers.push_back(handler);
00087   }
00088 
00089   /** 
00090    * Pop off the current handler and return it for cleanup, etc.
00091    * @return - last handler pushed onto the stack.
00092    */
00093   ErrHandler *Err::popHandler() {
00094     unsigned int count = getParam().m_ErrHandlers.size();
00095     if(count < 1) {
00096       Err::errAbort("Err::popHandler() - can't pop error handler when there aren't any left.");
00097     }
00098     ErrHandler *handler = getParam().m_ErrHandlers[count - 1];
00099     getParam().m_ErrHandlers.pop_back();
00100     return handler;
00101   }
00102 
00103   /** 
00104    * Give the current error handler a hint about whether or not to
00105    * throw exceptions.  Note that this is just a hint and that if a
00106    * specifical behavior is really required it is best to push a
00107    * custom error handler onto the stack.
00108    * 
00109    * @param doThrow - if true requesting exceptions to be thrown, if false not to be thrown
00110    */
00111   void Err::setThrowStatus(bool doThrow) {
00112     int size = getParam().m_ErrHandlers.size();
00113     for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
00114      ErrHandler *handler = getParam().m_ErrHandlers[i];
00115      handler->setThrows(doThrow);
00116     }
00117   }
00118 
00119   /** 
00120    * Return true if curerntly configured to throw exceptions on error, false otherwise.
00121    */ 
00122   bool Err::getThrowStatus() {
00123       ErrHandler *handler = getParam().m_ErrHandlers.back();
00124       return handler->getThrows();
00125   }
00126 
00127   /** 
00128    * Configure new error handler
00129    * 
00130    * @param doThrow - should an exception be thrown, or call exit
00131    * @param verbose - should the error handler call verbose methods
00132    */
00133    void Err::configureErrHandler(bool doThrow, bool verbose, bool exitOnError,
00134                                         int  exitOnErrorValue) {  
00135     VerboseErrHandler *handler = new VerboseErrHandler(doThrow, verbose, exitOnError, exitOnErrorValue);
00136     pushHandler(handler);
00137   }
00138 
00139   /** 
00140    * Toggle whether we are throwing exceptions or exiting on errors.
00141    * 
00142    * @param doThrow - if true exceptions will be thrown, if false exit(1) called.
00143    */
00144   void Err::setNewLineOnError(bool newline) {
00145     getParam().m_NewLineOnError = newline;
00146   }

00148 void Err::apt_err_assert(const std::string& file,int line,
00149                          const std::string& condstr,
00150                          bool cond,
00151                          const std::string& msg)
00152 {
00153   if (!cond) {
00154     std::string errmsg=file+":"+ToStr(line)+": '"+condstr+"'==false";
00155     if (msg!="") {
00156       errmsg+=" "+msg;
00157     }
00158     errAbort(errmsg);
00159   }
00160 }
00161 
00162 void Err::apt_err_abort(const std::string& file,int line,
00163                         const std::string& msg)
00164 {
00165   std::string errmsg=file+":"+ToStr(line)+": "+msg;
00166   errAbort(errmsg);
00167 }

00169 /**
00170   * Toggle whether to set the value returned when exiting on errors
00171   * This is primarily used to suppress Windows OS handling of
00172   * return values indicating an exe did not terminate successfully
00173 
00174   * if val is true, the value in setExitOnErrorValue will be
00175   * returned.
00176   */
00177 void Err::setExitOnError(bool val) {
00178         int size = getParam().m_ErrHandlers.size();
00179 
00180   if (size==0) {
00181     Verbose::warn(1,"Err::setExitOnError(): called without a handler present.");
00182   }
00183 
00184   for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
00185                 ErrHandler *handler = getParam().m_ErrHandlers[i];
00186                 handler->setExitOnError(val);
00187         }   
00188 }
00189 
00190  /**
00191   * Value to return when the flag setExitOnError is true and
00192   * exiting on errors
00193   */
00194 void Err::setExitOnErrorValue(int val) {
00195   int size = getParam().m_ErrHandlers.size();
00196 
00197   if (size==0) {
00198     Verbose::warn(1,"Err::setExitOnErrorValue(): called without a handler present.");
00199   }
00200 
00201   for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
00202                 ErrHandler *handler = getParam().m_ErrHandlers[i];
00203                 handler->setExitOnErrorValue(val);
00204         }
00205 }
